The atmosphere, however, is great. The colors, music, and art style are all very well done. The gameplay is solid, too. You have access to a variety of buildings for your base, and there are plenty of resource types. Traders will occasionally visit your base, which is helpful, especially early on. I really like the characters in the game; they each have traits and abilities, giving you a bit of role-playing potential. Almost everyone has both positive and negative sides, which adds depth to the experience.

I love the moral system. For example, you might have a character whoâ€™s a smoker and is upset because there arenâ€™t enough cigarettes stocked for him. If you donâ€™t keep his supply up, heâ€™ll get depressed. Or if you have a woman whoâ€™s a babysitter and you steal a log of wood from the soldiers, sheâ€™ll get depressed over your shameful actions. Each game takes about 40-45 days, and in the early days, it feels like youâ€™re truly surviving in a war-torn city. But after a while, it becomes repetitive. You start skipping days and just doing nothing. Once you figure out how the game works, it gets way too easy. I was just skipping days and feeding my group a mountain of canned food just to finish the campaign. It wasnâ€™t fun anymore.

You die because of the terrible combat controls, and then you have to replay the whole day and hope the game behaves the way you want it to during the next fight. Itâ€™s horrible.

This War of Mine is a game that depicts the much more harsh realities of surviving a war: Desperate, trapped in a city besieged by an army willing to commit whatever atrocities they wish, you're trapped inside; not as a soldier, but as a helpless civilian. Maybe you can, but your character might not be able to live with that guilt. There are many ways to lose the game, by simply dying as another casualty of war, committing suicide, dying by trying to escape in desperation, abandoning your shelter, even if you do survive, your characters would more than likely be racked with survivor's guilt, PTSD, and are forever scarred by the war. Not to mention buying this game and subsequent DLCs sends money to the Charity War Child, which is an organisation that helps support children in war-torn areas. This game is a reality check against the romanticization of war, and worth the purchase and playing experience.

Let me start by saying: [b] This War of Mine [/b] is my [u] FAVORITE [/u] game of all time.

Where as most games about war revolve around the action, the killing, the war itself, This War of Mine delves deeply into the [i] human cost [/i] of war itself. Your characters will starve, they will get depressed, and they will [spoiler] commit acts out of desperation and even commit suicide. [/spoiler]

You will be riddled with tough choices, and even tougher situations. As with most every day people living through a war, the goal is not to [i] harm others [/i] but rather to [i] ensure that you and your community [b] Survive. [/b][/i] You will need to build your base to prevent looters. You will need to actively defend yourself when patrolling for supplies. You can help others in your community to prolong their survival, or wait out their demise and loot what remains. 

Making ethically bad decisions can affect your gameplay drastically. Whether this is good or bad, is up to you, and the playthrough you have. Each one is different, difficult, and a fun journey. Often, some, or none of your characters will survive to the end. Often times, your neighbors will ask for help. Often times, your characters will cry, or wish they had a book, or reminisce. This is the nature of [b] war. [/b]

If you're a fan of survival games, base builders, in-depth stories, or war games, you should absolutely pick up This War of Mine. I've loved it for over a decade (Ignore my playtime, I played hundreds of hours of this when I was trapped without wifi in a different living situation) and so will you.
